comments.author: Don O

comments.text:
When installing gas shocks, keep the strap on the shock that is compressing 
it, until you get the new shock situated wherever it attaches to the 
vehicle, THEN cut the strap and allow the piston to pop out. The shock will 
automatically center itself in its mounts (you will probably have to hold 
it in position until the shock becomes fully extended). At that point, all 
you need to do is bolt the thing in. What that eliminates is unbolting the 
leaf springs, thus saving you a lot of time and keeps you from having to 
do a lot of unnecessary work....and the taller tires can eliminate his rear 
overhang problem, although it probably would've been smarter to go with a 
31 inch tall tire, in this case, rather than a 33. Home made lift kit would 
aid ground clearance and overhang problems even more. Now he doesn't have 
to cut up a perfectly good bed/tailgate and so, he's still able to use it 
as a pick-up truck.﻿

spools.﻿

comments.text:
my $400 83 s10 blazer is awesome off road. Factory 3.73's with a rear 
locker, shorter wheelbase and not much hanging out the back. I've had more 
problems dragging on the shackle than anything else, even stock. It's got a 
carbed 2.8 which sucks and stalls going up any steeper hills, but I'll be 
swapping to a fuel injected 4.3 sometime soon, but otherwise it's gone 
everywhere I've wanted it to.﻿

comments.author: Will Parker

comments.text:
I would have done 31x10.5R15 on cheap 8" wheels. 31" tires come stock on 
ZR2s so there are fewer problems (speedo correction, fitting, etc., 
especially for something that would be a daily driver). The slightly 
smaller tires means you can probably not do the suspension kit, saving some 
cash there, and not having to hack your back fenders or pull the flares. 
Cheap 8" wheels means you can get them new, instead of trying one's luck 
with used stuff (which has price and quality variances).﻿

comments.author: iJIMBUG

comments.text:
Aluminum front diff + 33 inch tires = parts on trail if used hard. If your 
lucky you can find a cast iron front diff out of a newer model with a 5 
speed but much better off just doing a SAS. I put Dana 60s front and rear 
under my 87 s10 blazer with leaf springs for under 1k by buying a pos ford 
that was rusted out. Wound up selling the engine, trans, and t-case for 
more than I gave for the whole truck.﻿
